markups: ''Characters whose creation players' have had some influence over.''

Many games provide gameplay by letting players control characters of some form. When the players have the chance of either creating these before gameplay begins or over time develop them to be as the players want, these are <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style>. Games with these allow players to customize not only the characters but through them the overall gameplay experience they will have. The downside to this is that it can take time and require knowledge to do this well, and can make it more difficult for game designers to provide narratives that have roles optimized for such characters.

Most <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> for an exception) support explicit rules for <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style>, although many scenarios include pre-made characters to allow gameplay to begin more quickly. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ars%20Magica">Ars Magica</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> are examples of such games where players spend points to determine attributes and other important characteristics, while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style> use dice. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallen%20Reich">Fallen Reich</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traveller">Traveller</link></style> make use of dice as well, but here to create background stories and through these the attributes, skills, etc.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> have take over several of these solutions, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> allowing players to spend points on attributes and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style> letting players roll what attributes their characters should have. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Witcher%20series">Witcher series</link></style> allow some customization in the beginning, e.g. which gender one will play in the two first examples, and through gradual choices through out the gameplay allow the character to be perceived to be at least partly created by players.

Typical aspects of <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> that are possible to change include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, the use of <style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style> (e.g. in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style>) can help players shape how their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should behave in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>.

Although it may be most natural that the pattern <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> is used to create <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, some games make use of the pattern to let player create <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> in roleplaying games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="workshopping">Workshopping</link></style> is the generic term for various specific techniques used to create or modify <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style>. They differ from other ways of instantiating <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> in that they are intended to be explicit gameplay activity and typically are done in groups.
In computer-based games, <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> are constructed in <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>.

Games supporting <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> gives players <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> in constructing <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, although the level of control and freedom may depend on the level of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> involved in the process. These <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, which may not only be <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> but can also be <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, are all examples of <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>. That players have created them increases the possibilities for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> and is likely to affect <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> if this is present in a game design. The personalization possible also allows players to construct <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player Defined Goals</link></style> for their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> as they are created, and can give them the <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> over how the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> will develop as well as letting them have influence on what type of <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> they can get to experience trying to make their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> reach their goals (this is due to players' having <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> while creating the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Initial%20Personalization">Initial Personalization</link></style>). Given that player can consider and choose the way they want <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> to behave while they are creating them, these <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are more likely to have <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> even if the behavior is decided by players rather than by game designers.

Although the creation of <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> typically takes place before gameplay properly begins, they are not <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> since they were not created by the game designers. However, game designers provide the rules for creating them so they can have heavy influence on what types of <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> are allowed. The time spent on <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> is an example of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Time%20Investments">Player Time Investments</link></style> and is likely to lead to <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, the use of <style="CurrentLink">Player-Created Characters</style> can be used to let them better fit the already existing <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>.
